P. 4306.(GAS MANTLES* ) Memorandum by the President of the Board of Trade.The safeguarding of Industrie e (No. 2) Order, 1923, was made by the Board of Trade on the 9th October, and imposes an import duty of Z3y&t- on "Mantles for incandescent lighting and component parts thereof whether finished or not'1, if manufactured in Germany, jThe Order wag made as the result of the unanimous report of a Committee constituted in accordance with the Act, and ae Parliament was not sitting and circumstances made it desirable not to delay, giving to the industry the protection to which it was entitled, the Board of Trade used the powers conferred upon them by Section %i4t) of the Act and made the Order during the Recess to come into force forthwith.The relevant portion of section 2 (4) of the Act reads as followe:-"In any other case /i. e* when the House of Commons Is not sitting and is not separated by such an adjournment or pro-prolongation as will expire within one month/7 an order may be made forthwith, but all orders so made shall be laid before the Commons House of Parliament as soon as may be after its next meeting, and shall not continue in force for more than one month after such meeting unless a resolution is passed by that House declaring that the orders shall continue in force, either without modification or subject to such modifications as may be specified in the resolution; and, if any modifica-tions are eo made as respects any order, the order shall thenceforth have effect subject to such modification, but without prejudice to the validity of anything previously done thereunder.Any order approved or continued under this subsection shall have effect as if enacted in this Act".The effect of this is that the present Order cauEt be confirmed by Resolution within one month of the date of the next meeting of the House, In the absence of such confirmation it will auto*-matlcally lapse.I should accordingly propose, if the Cabinet agree, to lay the requisite Resolution on the Table of the House, soon after Parliament assembles.(Initialled) P. LL. G.14th November, 1922.
